An 'aldose' is a monosaccharide (a simple sugar) that contains only one aldehyde
(-CH=O) group per molecule. The chemical formula takes the form
C n(H 2O) n. The simplest possible aldose is the
diose glycolaldehyde, which only contains two carbon atoms.

Because they have at least one asymmetric carbon center, aldoses with three or
more carbon atoms exhibit stereoisomerism. This means an aldose can exist in
either a D form or L form of a Fischer
projection. Biological systems tend to recognize D -aldoses more
than L -aldoses.

An aldose differs from a ketose in that it has a carbonyl group at the end of
the carbon chain instead of in the middle. This allows ketoses and aldoses to be
chemically differentiated through Seliwanoff's test. An aldose may
isomerize to a ketose through the Lobry-de Bruyn-van Ekenstein
transformation.
